comments.text:
Mmmm....ive been thinking exactly that for a few years now.." Ive lost everything I love"...this creates a terrible dreadful emotional response to this.I did lose a significant person in my life and my job and my home and income BUT I have realised over the last 6 years I didn't lose everything.
Its been hard yes...but it didn't kill me!
Thanks for this 😊

comments.text:
Awwww, Scott..😔 I'm sorry about the people or things you've lost..❤❤
This is REALLY useful information!! It's pretty "normal" to exaggerate when we talk to ourselves, I think. I often find myself thinking "I'm so ugly! Just hideous!" When in reality, it's more like "I'm not looking my best today". Or "I'm such an idiot!" When I should say "that was not a smart decision for someone who is usually fairly intelligent"
Knowing that my brain will actually believe the hyperbole gives me pause--and hopefully I will be more mindful of how  I talk to myself!!
comments.author: @kirstenvzumba9246

comments.author: @eenbrandmuis

comments.text: I have lost too much to ever recove. Yes it can always be worse, but if we keep lowering the bar to justify our miserable existence what is the point? I'm a realist. If I can't enjoy life and things don't get better than the game is obviously rigged right? Look, I appreciate your content but as a well informed realist that has suffered way too much already, Im tired of lowering the bar to make myself feel better. I'm not able to trick myself like that. Spirituality has it's limits, including religious beliefs....and spoiler - they don't pay the bills. I hate when im right about things I wish I was wrong about.
comments.author: @holla_j

Thank you, and thank you for continuing to make excellent content in spite of your losses.  You set an excellent example for us.  ❤

comments.text:
I do exactly this.  It's the way my birth family thought and I picked it up by osmosis, more-or-less. A couple of years ago, something I read  or heard in connection with a group therapy series gave me the space to realize, half-a-century later, that this is always an emotional over-reacting and that the reality is never as bad as it feels in the moment.  "It'll be better in the morning." 

It never even occurred to me to put a name to that practice. (Which is weird all on its own, but....) 

Life is a lot better since I learned to recognize when I'm doing it again and let it go.  

Still seems to be a common practice in the world around me, though.  Thanks so much for the name -- just that is going to be a great help recovering from it, and the term will be polished to a fine sheen before I'm through using it... 🥴
comments.author: @rcmwandering8653

comments.text: I grew up being abused and couldn't recognize sarcasm in others.  I thought I had to let people treat me however they wanted.  Wow, that's not true! 💥
comments.author: @positive-case

comments.text: It's taken me a long time, but I've had to learn that what I "lost" was worth losing in order for my wellbeing to be ok

Look, I appreciate your content but as a well informed realist that has suffered way too much already, Im tired of lowering the bar to make myself feel better. I'm not able to trick myself like that. Spirituality has it's limits, including religious beliefs....and spoiler - they don't pay the bills. I hate when im right about things I wish I was wrong about.
